history.content:
I would recommend starting with 113.  There tend to be more people in that class who haven't taken and upper div math class before (as opposed to, say, 104), so it tends to just assume Math 55 (or equivalently CS70) as background.  110 is also good in this regard, but in my experience, it ends up being mostly a rehash of Math 54 without anything really new, making it significantly less interesting.  Also, linear algebra is really just a very specific application of abstract algebra, so a bunch of the topics covered in 110 make way more sense if you're comfortable with the terminology of 113.

A good litmus test to see if you're likely to enjoy 113 is the number theory section of CS70 (ie, modular arithmetic, RSA, etc.), since 113 is where you learn why all of that stuff works.  If you liked that section of the course, you're likely to really enjoy 113.

(Also keep in mind the new policy for enrolling in math classes outlined in @5161--since you can't phase 1 these classes, which one you take may depend on which ones you can get in to in phase 2.)

-----

Just wanted to add that your experience in upper div. math courses are almost entirely dependent on what professor teaches that class. Upper div. math courses aren't one large class taught by one professor; they're usually small (at 35-40 people per class) with 5-6 professors teaching each "class." So, choose your professor well (which ties into the issue of not being able to Phase 1 UD Math courses; the "good" professors' classes fill up rather quickly). 

p.s. Avoid Wodzicki like the plague.

H113 with Wodizicki is fun tho :)

I'm a sophomore currently taking CS70, which I really enjoy. I'm now considering double majoring in Applied Math, but my only experience with a proof-based math course is 70. Which upper div math course would be most feasible alongside CS61C and CS170, or which would you recommend?
history.subject: Math Upper Div to take with 61C, 170
